comments.content:
Good advice for both experienced and  newly graduates. 

The product development triad - PM + DS / ENG / UX are collapsing a few years back; only accelerated in the age of AI. The only one that would survive and thrive all those who can ship E2E. 

Side note: I am surprised about this comment, 'many blank faces about the term "tech debt"''. Really?

comments.author: @Natenezz12
comments.content:
Within LLMs, jargon is compression.

Domain-specific terms collapse entire concepts into a few tokens and route the model into high-precision reasoning paths.
If you want better results from AI, learn the language of the domain. That may mean taking a CS class, learning basic math notation, or understanding engineering principlesâ€”not to code, but to communicate precisely. For some coding is easier that the mastery of communication through language.

Precision beats verbosity. You still must study and learn domain knowledge. 

Example of an expert in ML prompting a LLM:
"In a discounted infinite-horizon MDP with continuous state and action spaces, Iâ€™m seeing policy oscillation under standard Bellman optimality updates.
How would you stabilize convergence by modifying the Bellman backupâ€”e.g., through soft Bellman operators, entropy regularization, or conservative Q-updatesâ€”without sacrificing asymptotic optimality?"

Example of  a non-expert prompting : 
â€œI want to find the reward for a few business decisions at work.â€

What do you think the results will be for each end user of the LLM? Which kind user do you think finds the best solution the fastest?  Still feel like an engineering degree is a waste of time? Think again.
